The development of roads may also bring subsequent impacts on further development
intensity due to increasing economic activities (see Chapter 8) mostly in the tropics and subtropics,
where the expansion of road networks increases access to remote forests
(Box 7.1). Logging is one of the main drivers of road construction
which leads to more severe long term impacts that
increased fire incidence, soil erosion, landslides, and sediment accumulation in streams,
biological invasions, wildlife poaching, illicit land colonisation, illegal logging and mining, land
Rapidly expanding roads, particularly in tropical regions, are linked to forest loss,
adjacent to roads also drives speculation and deforestation related to land tenure
poorly planned, infrastructure can facilitate fires, illegal mining, and wildlife poaching with
consequences for GHG emissions and biodiversity conservation. However, some
providing new approaches for better planning and then limit environmental and societal impacts
Although the number and extent of protected areas has increased markedly in recent decades
, many other indicators reveal that nature is in broad retreat. For exam
intact wilderness is declining rapidly worldwide
now less than 1 km from a forest edge
, the extent of tropical forest fragmentation
. One of the most direct and immediate driver of
deforestation and biodiversity decline is the dramatic expansion of roads and other transportation
(Laurance et al. 2014a; Laurance and Arrea 2017; Alamgir et al. 2017)
From 2010 to 2050, the total length of paved roads is projected to incre
95% of all deforestation occurs within 5.5 km of a road, and for every km of legal road there are nearly
More than any other proximate factor, the dramatic exp
ansion of roads is determining the pace and
patterns of habitat disruption and its impacts on biodiversity
. Much road expansion is poorly planned. Environmental Impact Assessments (EIAs) for roads
and other infrastructure are typically too short
term and superficial to detect rare species or assess long
term or indirect impacts of projec
the consideration of each project in isolation from other existing or planned developments
. Hence, EIAs alone are inadequate for planning infrastructure projects and assessing their
